title: 8 books shortlisted for $75K U.S. Cundill History Prize | CBC Books
text:
Eight titles have been shortlisted for the Cundill History Prize, a $75,000 U.S. ($99,427 Cdn) award administered by McGill University that is awarded to the year's best work of historical nonfiction.

Yale professor David Blight is on the list for his book Frederick Douglass: American Prophet, which the jury described as "the definitive biography" of the celebrated abolitionist orator. The book won the 2019 Pulitzer Prize for history.

Jill Lepore, a Harvard historian and New Yorker staff writer, is a finalist for These Truths: A History of the United States. The book takes on the American story starting from 1492, exploring the intersections of governance, sovereignty and media across the centuries.

Here's the full shortlist:

Unruly Waters: How Rains, Rivers, Coasts, and Seas Have Shaped Asia's History by Sunil Amrith

Orphans of Empire: The Fate of London's Foundlings by Helen Berry

Frederick Douglass: American Prophet by David Blight

Reckonings: Legacies of Nazi Persecution and the Quest for Justice by Mary Fulbrook

A Fistful of Shells: West Africa from the Rise of the Slave Trade to the Age of Revolution by Toby Green

American Eden: David Hosack, Botany, and Medicine in the Garden of the Early Republic by Victoria Johnson

These Truths: A History of the United States by Jill Lepore

Maoism: A Global History by Julia Lovell

The jury is comprised of Charlotte Gray, Robert Gerwarth, Jane Kamensky and Rana Mitter. They will select the winner, along with two runners up.

The three finalists will be announced on Oct. 16, 2019, followed by the winner on Nov. 14, 2019.

The 2018 winner was Maya Jasaonoff for The Dawn Watch: Joseph Conrad in a Global World.
description: Pulitzer Prize winner David Blight and New Yorker writer Jill Lepore are among the finalists. The award recognizes the year's best work of historical nonfiction.
